message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms mentioned in the question suggest amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Among the options, only Riluzole has been shown to slow the progression of the disease. Nusinersen is used to treat spinal muscular atrophy, Glatiramer acetate is used to treat multiple sclerosis, and inactivated virus vaccine is used for protection against viral infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of degeneration of corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells with asymmetrical atrophy of limb muscles, diaphragm, and intercostal muscles suggest motor neuron disease, which can be treated with Riluzole. Nusinersen is used to treat spinal muscular atrophy, glatiramer acetate is used to treat multiple sclerosis, and inactivated virus vaccine is used to prevent viral infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms match amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), and Riluzole is the only drug among the options approved for ALS treatment that might slow the progression of the disease. Nusinersen is used to treat spinal muscular atrophy, not ALS. Glatiramer acetate is used for multiple sclerosis. Inactivated virus vaccine is not used to treat neurological conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest that the patient had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Of the options provided, only Riluzole has been shown to slow the progression of ALS. Nusinersen is used to treat spinal muscular atrophy, Glatiramer acetate is used to treat multiple sclerosis, and inactivated virus vaccine is used to prevent viral infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and autopsy findings suggest a diagnosis of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). Riluzole is currently the only FDA-approved drug for the treatment of ALS and has been shown to slow the progression of the disease. Nusinersen is used to treat Spinal Muscular Atrophy, which has a different etiology and presentation than ALS. Glatiramer acetate is used in multiple sclerosis, while inactivated virus vaccines are used to prevent viral infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and autopsy findings suggest that the patient had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Riluzole is the only drug approved for slowing the progression of ALS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms indicate motor neuron disease, possibly Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). Riluzole is the only FDA-approved drug to slow the progression of ALS. Nusinersen is used for spinal muscular atrophy, which usually presents much earlier in life. Glatiramer acetate is used for multiple sclerosis, and inactivated virus vaccine is for preventing viral infections. None of these are likely to slow the progression of motor neuron disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms point towards Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, which causes progressive degeneration of motor neurons. Riluzole is the only FDA-approved drug for ALS which can slow down the progression of the disease. Nusinersen is used to treat spinal muscular atrophy, and Glatiramer acetate is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Inactivated virus vaccine is not relevant to this patient’s condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Motor Neuron Disease (MND). Riluzole is the only drug approved for treating MND, which can slow progression of the disease by reducing the release of glutamate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autopsy findings suggest that the patient had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), and Riluzole is the only drug approved for slowing the progression of ALS. Nusinersen is used for spinal muscular atrophy, Glatiramer acetate is used for multiple sclerosis, and inactivated virus vaccine is used for preventing viral infections. None of them are indicated for ALS.
